Article Title: Netflix is increasing prices again across plans: New pricing, price hike timeline and all other details
Article Text: Netflix is increasing price across all subscription tiers in the United States, including the first-ever hike for its ad-supported plan.The standard ad-free plan will see the largest increase, jumping $2.50 to $17.99 per month. The ad-supported tier will rise by $1 to $7.99, while the premium plan will increase by $2 to $24.99 monthly. The changes take effect immediately for new subscribers and will roll out to existing customers in their next billing cycle."As we continue to invest in programming and deliver more value for our members, we will occasionally ask our members to pay a little more so that we can re-invest to further improve Netflix," the company stated in its letter to investors.The price hikes coincide with Netflix's announcement of adding 18.9 million subscribers in Q4 2024, its largest quarterly increase ever, bringing its global subscriber count to 300 million. The company's co-CEO Greg Peters defended the pricing strategy, particularly for the ad-supported tier: "We believe that our starting price, even after the price increase, is an incredible entertainment value. And it's a highly accessible entry point."This marks Netflix's first price adjustment since October 2023, when it increased costs for its basic and premium plans while maintaining the prices of its standard and ad-supported tiers. The streaming service also revealed that over 55% of new sign-ups in markets where advertising is available opted for the ad-supported plan in Q4.The price increases will also affect subscribers in Canada, Portugal, and Argentina. Netflix has raised its 2025 revenue outlook to between $43.5 billion and $44.5 billion, up $500 million from its previous forecast, while projecting an operating margin of 29%.
Article Summary: Netflix is increasing prices across all subscription tiers in the U.S. The standard ad-free plan will see the largest increase, jumping $2.50 to $17.99 per month. Mao used four different accounts to maintain his fake identities, pretending to be various people. His downfall came when Tang unknowingly took a photo of his car‚Äôs license plate, which helped authorities track him down. After collecting evidence, Mao was arrested in Shanghai and sentenced to 10 and a half years in prison with a 100,000 yuan fine (approximately Rs 11 lakh).Tang, living on a modest pension, fell deeply into debt due to Mao‚Äôs manipulative tactics, owing over 70,000 yuan (around Rs 8 lakh). Despite the restrictions, no official announcement was made until August 2024, when millions of users had already experienced connectivity issues. The ban was seen as a move to curb dissent and control public discourse.However, government officials, including Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, have continued to use X, most likely through Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). Article Title: OpenAI, Arm, Oracle to lead America‚Äôs biggest-ever AI infrastructure project in history
Article Text:
Masayoshi Son, SoftBank Group CEO, from left, Larry Ellison, chairman of Oracle Corporation and chief technology officer, and Sam Altman, OpenAI CEO listen to President Donald Trump in the Roosevelt Room at the White House, Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025, in Washington. (AP Photo/Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

President Donald Trump announced Tuesday what he called "the largest AI infrastructure project in history," a joint venture between OpenAI , Oracle , and SoftBank that aims to invest up to $500 billion in artificial intelligence infrastructure across the United States.The project, dubbed Stargate, will begin with a $100 billion investment to construct data centers and computing infrastructure, with plans to expand investment to $500 billion over the next four years.Trump said the project would create "over 100,000 American jobs almost immediately.""What we want to do is we want to keep it in this country," Trump said at the White House announcement, flanked by tech executives. "China is a competitor and others are competitors. We want it to be in this country."OpenAI CEO Sam Altman , who will oversee operations while SoftBank handles financing, called it "the most important project of this era." SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son will serve as chairman of Stargate.Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison revealed that ten data centers are already under construction in Texas, with plans for additional sites across the country. "AI holds incredible promise for all of us, for every American," Ellison said.Trump pledged to expedite the project's development through emergency declarations, particularly regarding energy infrastructure. "They have to produce a lot of electricity and we'll make it possible for them to get that production done very easily at their own plants," he said.The venture includes other technology partners such as Microsoft , Nvidia, and Arm . Middle East AI fund MGX will join SoftBank in its investment capacity.The announcement comes one day after Trump's inauguration and his reversal of predecessor Joe Biden's executive order on AI safety standards. The investment aligns with broader market projections ‚Äì financial firm Blackstone had already estimated $1 trillion in U.S. data center investments over five years."This monumental undertaking is a resounding declaration of confidence in America's potential under a new president," Trump said.
Article Summary: The project, dubbed Stargate, will begin with a $100 billion investment to construct data centers and computing infrastructure, with plans to expand investment to $500 billion over the next four years. Article Title: Indonesia fines Google $12.37 million, here‚Äôs why
Article Text:
Previous fines on Google

Indonesia's antitrust agency has announced that Google has been ordered to pay a fine of 202 billion rupiah ($12.37 million) for engaging in unfair business practices through its payment system services on the Google Play Store.According to a report by news agency Reuters, the investigation, launched in 2022, examined allegations that Google had abused its dominant market position by requiring Indonesian app developers to use Google Pay Billing .This system allegedly charged higher rates than other available payment options, with developers facing removal from the Play Store if they did not comply.Google has previously defended its practices, stating that it had implemented a system allowing developers to offer users an alternative billing option. However, the Indonesian regulator determined that the company's actions amounted to anticompetitive behavior, leading to the significant penalty.Google has faced multiple fines, including a ‚Ç¨2.4 billion fine from India, the European Union and a large fine from Russia.The Competition Commission of India (CCI) fined Google Rs 1,337.76 crore for anti-competitive practices related to Android devices. The CCI imposed the penalty on October 20, 2022. Google paid the entire penalty. The CCI also imposed a penalty of Rs 936.44 crore on Google for abusing its dominant position with respect to its Play Store policies.In 2017, Google was fined 2.4 billion pounds (about Rs 26,172 crore) for abusing its market dominance by unfairly penalising a price comparison website, Foundem. Google was also ordered to pay to a UK couple named Shivaun and Adam Raff. The couple won a 15-year legal battle after Google pushed their price comparison website Foundem down in search results.Russia fined Google a large sum that's been described as ‚Äúmore than Earth's entire wealth‚Äù, acknowledging the fine‚Äôs symbolic significance.
Article Summary: Indonesia's antitrust agency has announced that Google has been ordered to pay a fine of 202 billion rupiah ($12.37 million) The investigation, launched in 2022, examined allegations that Google had abused its dominant market position. Google has faced multiple fines, including a ‚Ç¨2.4 billion fine from India, the European Union and a large fine from Russia.

Article Title: 'Nothing is changing...', Facebook-parent Meta on fact-checking strategy globally
Article Text:
Meta ends fact-checking partnerships ahead of Donald Trump‚Äôs inauguration

Facebook-parent company Meta will continue employing third-party fact-checkers outside the US ‚Äúfor now,‚Äù even as it phases out the practice domestically, a senior executive from the company has said. In the US, Meta plans to replace its third-party fact-checking efforts with a community-driven ‚Äúnotes system.‚ÄùNicola Mendelsohn, Meta‚Äôs head of global business, made the announcement during an interview with Bloomberg at the World Economic Forum in Davos, saying that the company intends to evaluate the effectiveness of this change domestically before considering whether to implement similar shifts in other regions.‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see how that goes as we move it out over the year,‚Äù Mendelsohn was quoted as saying.‚ÄúSo nothing [is] changing in the rest of the world at the moment, we are still working with those fact checkers around the world,‚Äù she added.The move aligns with CEO Mark Zuckerberg ‚Äôs recent remarks ‚Äì which came days ahead of Donald Trump‚Äôs inauguration ‚Äì on scaling back the nearly decade-old fact-checking program, originally established to combat viral hoaxes on the platform.Zuckerberg cited ‚Äútoo many mistakes‚Äù and complaints of unfair censorship as reasons for the shift. He even accused former COO Sheryl Sandberg for the "culture" in Facebook in a meeting with Trump's advisor Stephen Miller.As per a report in New York Times Zuckerberg blamed Sandberg for Facebook's inclusivity initiative, which saw employees embrace self-expression in the workplace. He also hinted that the new guidelines and layoffs will be initiated to ‚Äúreset the company.‚ÄùHowever, he acknowledged that applying this approach internationally would face additional challenges due to stricter regulatory environments, such as the European Union‚Äôs Digital Services Act . The Act mandates large platforms to actively combat deceptive political content and misinformation, with noncompliance risking significant penalties.
Article Summary: Facebook-parent company Meta will continue employing third-party fact-checkers outside the US ‚Äúfor now,‚Äù even as it phases out the practice domestically. In the US, Meta plans to replace its fact-checking efforts with a community-driven ‚Äúnotes system.‚Äù

Article Title: Telecom minister Jyotiraditya Scindia on allocating spectrum for satellite services: 'My job is to‚Ä¶'
Article Text:
Elon Musk-Reliance tussle over satellite spectrum

Telecom Minister Jyotiraditya Scindia has defended the decision to allocate spectrum for satellite services, instead of auctioning it off, saying that he wants users to have as many choices as possible.‚ÄúMy job as telecoms minister is to make sure that you have as many choices as possible,‚Äù Scindia told news agency Reuters during an interview. Allocating the spectrum instead of auctioning aligns with the global trend.An administrative allocation has been met with opposition from Reliance Jio , which had advocated for an auction process.Led by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, the telco had expressed concerns that an administrative allocation would favor foreign players like Elon Musk's Starlink , potentially eroding its market share.Scindia, however, acknowledged the dynamic nature of technology, emphasizing the need for companies to continuously adapt and evolve.‚ÄúTechnology is never constant,‚Äù Scindia said in a reply when asked if there was merit in Reliance's concerns, adding that companies need to keep evolving.He noted that satellite-based services require a clear line of sight to the sky, rendering them unsuitable for indoor use, unlike terrestrial networks.India's telecom market, with over 942 million users, is a highly competitive landscape with Reliance Jio, Bharti Airtel, and Vodafone Idea vying for the largest market share.India‚Äôs satellite broadband market is projected to reach $1.9 billion by 2030, according to Deloitte, making it an attractive market for players like Starlink, Amazon Kuiper, and other global players.As per Scindia, the Starlink and Amazon Kuiper's applications for a licence to launch satellite broadband services in the country are under review.
Article Summary: Telecom Minister Jyotiraditya Scindia has defended the decision to allocate spectrum for satellite services, instead of auctioning it off. An administrative allocation has been met with opposition from Reliance Jio, which had advocated for an auction process.

Article Title: The Brutalist editor reveals that makers used AI in the Golden Globe-winning film, There's nothing in the film using AI that hasn't been done before"

Article Title: US President Donald Trump revokes Biden's AI safety order: What the original order said
Article Text:
US President Donald Trump revoked an AI regulation order by Joe Biden aimed at mitigating AI risks. The order required developers to share safety test results before releasing potentially harmful AI systems.

What Biden‚Äôs AI order said



US President Donald Trump has revoked an executive order related to artificial intelligence (AI) passed by Joe Biden in 2023. Aimed at mitigating risks associated with AI, including threats to consumers, workers, and national security, the order mandated developers to conduct and share safety test results with the US government before releasing systems deemed potentially harmful to national security, the economy, or public health, under the guidelines of the Defense Production Act.In 2024, the Republican Party platform pledged to repeal the order, arguing that it stifles AI innovation and emphasised that ‚ÄúRepublicans support AI development grounded in free speech and the promotion of human flourishing.‚ÄùTrump began his first full day in office on January 21, following an inauguration that set a fundraising record of over $250 million. Shortly after taking the oath, he also signed executive orders addressing immigration, environmental policies, and government operations.The order also instructed agencies to establish standards for AI safety testing and address associated risks, including chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and cybersecurity threats. Biden introduced the order as US lawmakers struggled to pass legislation to regulate AI development.Generative AI, which can produce text, images, and videos in response to prompts, has generated both excitement and concerns, particularly over its potential to displace jobs or cause other negative impacts.Last week, the US Commerce Department imposed new restrictions on AI chip and technology exports, facing criticism from industry leaders, including Nvidia.Separately, Biden issued another executive order last week to support the growing energy demands of advanced AI data centres. This order proposed the leasing of federal sites managed by the Defense and Energy departments. However, Trump has yet to repeal this order.Apart from this, Trump has also issued orders freezing government hiring and mandating federal employees return to full-time, in-person work. This move has sparked opposition from unions representing public sector workers.
Article Summary: The order required developers to share safety test results before releasing potentially harmful AI systems. In 2024, the Republican Party platform pledged to repeal the order, arguing that it stifles AI innovation. Generative AI has generated both excitement and concerns, particularly over its potential to displace jobs or cause other negative impacts.
